newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Big Australian retailers face identity crisis.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Big Australian retailers face identity crisis.

text.p: In an identity crisis of sorts, Australia's largest grocery retailer, Woolworths Ltd, wants to become more like a petrol (gasoline) station.
Meanwhile, the nation's biggest petrol station chain, Australian Petroleum Ltd (Ampol), wants to be more like a grocer.
It's all about roping in customers.
Both companies are feeling the impact of higher costs, which are hitting the bottom line.
Woolworths on Wednesday reported a steady profit in tough trading in 1995/96 of A$233.6 million, well down on the previous year's growth rates.

Profits of Ampol's 50 percent owner, Caltex Australia Ltd, although up nearly three-fold to A$30.31 million in 1995/96, still were constrained by high crude oil prices, the company said on Wednesday. Ampol's other owner is building products group, Pioneer International Ltd.
Ampol said margins on gasoline sales are too small on their own, so why not sell newspapers, pizza, milk and over-the-counter medications to boost revenues.
In current conditions petrol stations earn only about one cent per litre after tax on petrol sales as opposed to often hefty premiums on grocery and convenience items.
Woolworth's says shoppers regularly fill up in supermarket parking lots in Europe and the United States and predicts they will do the same in Australia.
"We announce today that Woolworths will embark upon the retailing of petrol," Woolworths managing director Reg Clairs told a news conference in Sydney on Wednesday.
Not surprisingly, Ampol thinks its idea is better.
"I think if you're modelling Europe and projecting whether or not those market conditions could eventuate in Australia, I think it's very unlikely," Ian Blackburne, managing director of Ampol said.
Blackburne said established pipeline systems for distributing petrol easily in Europe do not exist in Australia.
"Somebody that is going to participate in petrol retailing has got to go through the mechanics of importing, of terminalling and of distribution," he said.
Woolworths obviously see things differently and will spend A$4.5 million initially to build its first station in rural Dubbo, New South Wales, by October to get the ball rolling.
The outlet would be the first of many and up to half the 1,031 Woolworths stores in Australia could have petrol stations in their carparks in the next few year
For its part, Ampol is moving deeper into offering non-petroleum products and services at its retail stations.
It is in the process of extending trials into convenience retailing to a further 20 sites, Blackburne said.
"We've introduced new consumer offerings with 'Pizza Haven' and 'Muffin Break,' Blackburne said.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
